urn:contentItem:6GBF-2S83-RV8J-R290-00000-00Video shows burning PVC decking self-extinguishing2025-07-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T17:02:11ZLexisNexisPg. 18Video shows burning PVC decking self-extinguishingCatherine Kavanaugh

Chicago-based TimberTech released a demonstration video of how its Advanced PVC decking compares with other decking materials during a fire.

The demonstration involved lighting burners simultaneously under three kinds of board: TimberTech's Vintage-brand Advanced PVC decking, which meets standards for Class A flame spread; a capped wood-plastic composite that meets Class B standards; and a mineral-based composite that meets Class C standards. Building materials are classified from A to D based on how far and how quickly flames spread across their surface materials. The Class A flame-spread rating signifies a material with the highest resistance to flames.

In addition to the Class A flame spread rating, TimberTech describes its decking as Advanced PVC because it has a four-sided cap around a durable core made from a blend of virgin and recycled polymers. The decking doesn't contain any wood or organic fillers, which the company says can compromise long-term performance in the core or cap and opens up competitor boards to rot.

The TimberTech brand was part of Azek Co. until July 1, when James Hardie Industries plc completed its acquisition of Azek in a cash and stock transaction representing a value of $8.4 billion.

With $990 million in estimated annual related sales, Azek Co.'s TimberTech brand is No. 8 in Plastics News' ranking North American pipe, profile and tubing extruders.

In the new video, as a disclaimer, the announcer says the TimberTech test was done for demonstration only and isn't representative of the actual ASTM E-84 surface flame spread test.

In the controlled-environment demonstration, after the burners were lit, the video shows flames reach up between the test boards of all three types of decking materials.

At one minute, all the burners are turned off, which comes at about the 40-second point of the video, which is just over a minute long. The video shows the flames quickly recede from the Advanced PVC decking.

"It's been just a few seconds, and the TimberTech Vintage board has already self-extinguished," the announcer says.

Both the Class B and Class C boards were still burning nine minutes after the burners were turned off, according to the video.

"This demo showed that the TimberTech Advanced PVC Vintage board with the Class A flame spread rating outperformed the wood-capped composite and mineral base boards when exposed to flame," the video concludes.

The demonstration results highlight the value of TimberTech PVC decking for fire-conscious homeowners wanting to protect outdoor spaces from accidental ignition sources like grills or stray embers from firepits, according to Jonathan Skelly, Azek president, residential and commercial.

"TimberTech's performance in this fire comparison test is a clear demonstration of the innovation and engineering behind our Advanced PVC decking," Skelly said in a news release. "As fire safety and climate resilience become increasingly important in material selection, we're proud to offer products that meet the highest-performance standards - without sacrificing the beauty and design versatility professionals expect, or the low-maintenance durability homeowners rely on."

In addition to Vintage, TimberTech's Landmark and Harvest+ PVC product lines meet standards for Class A flame spread.

TimberTech put a link of the video demonstration on its newly launched website for architects and designers. The online resource center says utilizing fire-resistant materials like TimberTech decking and cladding can make a big difference during a wildfire event. "For architects, this means integrating solutions that slow flame spread, resist ignition and combat one of wildfires' biggest dangers: flying embers," the website says.

The Vintage and Landmark decking lines also meet standards for "ignition-resistant," which California and surrounding states adopted, and the Wildland Urban Interface (WUI), or fire-prone regions where local building codes mandate fire-resistant materials for construction projects.

TimberTech Harvest+ decking has been WUI Certified and is Class A flame spread rated but is awaiting Ignition Resistance testing.

In a May earnings call before the acquisition, Azek officials reaffirmed expectations for 2025 fiscal year sales in the range of $1.52 billion to $1.55 billion, representing an increase of about 5-8 percent year over year.
